race.name: Sunday Creek Classic
race.tagline: Queensland hinterland gravel through dairy country.

climate.description: Warm conditions typical. Variable Queensland weather.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Queensland hinterland dairy country. Rolling to hilly terrain with moderate elevation.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Small grassroots Queensland event. Affordable and community-focused but very limited infrastructure and field.

biased_opinion.summary: Sunday Creek Classic is a small grassroots gravel race in Queensland's hinterland dairy country. Kenilworth is tiny, amenities are minimal, and the field is small. It's an honest local event with rolling terrain and affordable pricing, but it's not trying to be more than a regional ride for Queensland cyclists.
weaknesses: Very small town with minimal amenities
Tiny field with no competitive depth
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A small local gravel race in rural Queensland. Perfect for locals who want an affordable weekend ride. Not worth traveling for unless you're already in the area or combining with hinterland tourism.

final_verdict.one_liner: Small grassroots Queensland hinterland ride with modest ambitions.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Only if you're local to Queensland and want an affordable, low-key gravel ride. Not worth traveling for.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Queensland events: Noosa Gravel Enduro. For similar grassroots vibes: other regional Australian events.

logistics.airport: Brisbane (BNE) 1.5-2 hours drive, or Sunshine Coast Airport (MCY) 1 hour
logistics.lodging_strategy: Very limited lodging in Kenilworth. Stay in nearby towns or Sunshine Coast. Book early.
logistics.food: Small town with minimal dining. Stock up beforehand.

history.origin_story: Grassroots gravel event in Queensland hinterland.

course_description.character: Rolling hinterland gravel through dairy country.
course_description.signature_challenge: Rolling hinterland terrain and Queensland heat.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: 62 miles of Queensland hinterland dairy country gravel.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Small grassroots event in rural Kenilworth.

logistics.explanation: 7 AM start from Kenilworth Showground is straightforward, with $20 camping available on-site and hot showers for $1 coin. The town offers basic amenities - Kenilworth Bakery closes at 3pm, catching late finishers. Semi-supported means one resupply at Jimna Base Camp (74km), leaving riders self-sufficient for the final 46km stretch back to town. As Imogen Smith puts it: "At the 40km mark we shared a passionate bit of grovelling up Mt Buggery, a key feature in the event marketing campaign."

length.explanation: Elite rider Imogen Smith's nutrition disaster illustrates the distance perfectly: "With a severe shortage of gels, having sucked down four in the first hour alone, I stuffed handfuls of jelly snakes up my jersey and ate them like spaghetti for the next 40 kilometres." She finished "utterly, totally spent after 6.5 hours of riding" with a TSS of 425, showing 120km hits the sweet spot for proper suffering. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Water crossings force tactical decisions - Imogen Smith encountered "a deep causeway" where "the guy at the front shook his head and dismounted 'I'm not riding into that'." The course features mandatory hike-a-bike through "impossible head-high moto ruts" and Sunday Creek Road descent described as "a collection of sharp rocks held together like extreme nougat." Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: Mt Buggery at 5.3km gaining 500m defines the climbing, with "gradients that top out just a whisker under 30%." Even Shimano GRX 12-speed gearing couldn't handle the steepest ramps, forcing Imogen Smith to walk sections she'd previously ridden on her mountain bike. The 3,000m total over 120km creates sustained vertical punishment throughout. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: Late May in Queensland should be mild autumn weather, but there's zero historical weather data available for race day conditions. You're gambling on temperature, rain, and wind with no intel to guide equipment or pacing decisions. The course goes through different climate zones from dry forest to rainforest, so conditions could vary significantly within the same ride. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego. As Imogen Smith puts it: "The descent along Sunday Creek Road made me rethinking my bike choice – all you could do was let go of the brakes and grit your teeth."

altitude.explanation: Queensland's Sunshine Coast hinterland keeps elevation low enough that altitude never factors into performance or training considerations. The course traverses from Kenilworth through forest and cattle country without reaching elevations where thin air becomes relevant. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Remote sections offer isolation - "There are long stretches away from any support. This is also the beautiful part of the event." Riders traverse "dark and moody" Imbil State Forest under "towering native pines" that "block out virtually all light," then emerge into cattle grazing country. Navigation challenges exist with multiple riders experiencing wrong turns despite pink tape marking.

prestige.explanation: This is a baby race that started in 2022 - barely old enough to have established any meaningful reputation. Wild&Co calls it 'one of the toughest one day gravel events on the Australian calendar,' but when you're comparing against a field of maybe twelve other races, that's not saying much. No notable winners, no pro field, no international recognition - just regional Queensland tourism sites hyping it up.

race_quality.explanation: The course design hits the basics with 120km through Jimna to Sunday Creek and back, but execution feels amateur hour. Semi-supported means you're mostly on your own between water stops, and there's no mention of timing systems, results processing, or professional race management. For a race claiming to be among Australia's toughest, the organizational infrastructure reads like a weekend club ride with entry fees. As Race Director Chris Dixon puts it: "Expect this to be tough, very tough – this event is only for those who can race and complete a hard core challenge. There will be minimal support during large sections of the event."

experience.explanation: The course transitions from "dark and moody" native pine plantations to open cattle country, offering terrain diversity. Jimna Base Camp at 74km provides the sole resupply with "excellent hot coffee, cookies, chocolate bars" from owner Peter Cusack. Post-race atmosphere centers on Kenilworth's pub serving "the finest cold beverages in the valley."

community.explanation: Wild&Co is building something with their Gravel Classics brand, expanding to the Kyogle Classic in 2026, so they're not just running one event and disappearing. The 'great turnout for 2025' suggests people are coming back, which means someone's doing something right. But with zero online community presence or rider discussions findable anywhere, the community exists only on race day.

field_depth.explanation: No pro riders, no notable winners, no mention of competitive categories - this is pure weekend warrior territory. The race is 'bigger than ever' for 2026, but when you start from maybe 50 riders, doubling still gets you nowhere near competitive depth. If you want to race fast people, look elsewhere. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: The race delivers 120km of varied terrain with 3,000m climbing through Queensland backcountry, plus camping at race HQ for $20. Organizer Chris Dixon's dual goals include supporting "small town economies like Kenilworth" through cycling tourism. No published entry fees suggest reasonable pricing for what amounts to an organized sufferfest through pristine hinterland.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $60-100 AUD. Kenilworth is 2-3 hours from Brisbane or Gold Coast airports, so you're looking at rental car costs but not internal flights. Accommodation options aren't detailed because there probably aren't many - expect basic motel or camping situations. Food and lodging in rural Queensland won't break the bank, but don't expect luxury either. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
